dict.string: words are pointers.
we can't describe every word by using other words.
meaning must involve a connection between language and something other than language.
the cognitive approach to meaning
the meaning of the word cat for individuals is their prototypical mental representation of a cat.
meanings are associated with mental representations.
option1: language connects with concepts and ideas in the mind.
CE5E02DC-2B7A-4324-A803-DD2BFE39C0C4
the referential approach to meaning
D3ABFC5E-AAE9-4781-A169-FEFE5138C19D
the meaning of the word cat is the set of all cats in the world.
a word points to real world things.
option 2: language connects with the world.
what does it mean for a word to mean something?
DB12F110-BACC-496F-8ED8-A17BA14AC2E6
referential approach works better than cognitive approach
compositionally is important in syntax: may get structurally ambiguous
in how words combine together into sentences to create meanings.
formal semantics is interested in more than just the meaning of individuals words.
F803AABF-D2AC-47CE-B9B0-0DB4C780CC0B
1. what individual words mean
what are the principles of semantic composition?
2. how words combine to create new, complex meanings
A3AFFD85-B5AC-4B95-A1FE-23C389DE511E
formal semanticists believe that knowing what a sentence means, means knowing the conditions under which the sentence is true or false.
8EAC0ECA-FFAC-4696-AC2E-359619BB0FEB
semantics is truth conditional in this sense.
we are looking for steps to predict whether a statement is true or not, under certain conditions, just from the individual word meanings and principles of composition.
3. how the truth of a statement logically follows from the principles of composition.
3 things need to be known
how do the meaning of words combine to make new meanings?
words and phrases
336C0DB7-2C66-4BD6-B944-C0FAFDB56BCD
to analyze semantic compositions (i.e., sentence meanings), often start with imagined and simplified worlds, called models.
a few individuals (like Arnold, Beth, Chris, Denise)
843BB326-A5F6-49FC-80ED-8B0EC21FEA5B
a few properties that these individuals can have.
models: a model is a simplified sketch of the world and contains:
the referential approach to meaning treats the meaning of a world is a pointer to something in the world.
Proper nouns refer to individuals in the world.
a property is something that holds of an individual or doesn't. thus verb point to all the individuals who have a specific property.
the meaning of a verb is the set of individuals which share the property associated with the verb.

using a compositional rule that can take the meaning of a noun and the meaning of a verb and get us the meaning of a sentence. (where a sentence consists of the elements [Noun Verb], the meaning of the sentence is true only if the Noun refers to one of the individuals with the property described by the Verb in our model.)

\f0\fs24 \cf0 using a compositional rule that can take \b the meaning of a noun \b0 and \b the meaning of a verb \b0 and get us \b the meaning of a sentence. \b0 (where a sentence consists of the elements [Noun Verb], the meaning of the sentence is true only if the Noun refers to one of the individuals with the property described by the Verb in our model.)}
5929862E-311E-4AC7-BFBD-F0B86BEDB8AA
simple and intuitive!
this compositional rule provides a meaning for our sentence now: the meaning is either TRUE or FALSE depending on what's going on in our model.
a principle of composition
conjunctures and quantifiers
a simplified semantic framework
SEMANTICS
utterances: things we actually say.
every time we speak, we are in a certain context: a time, a place, who we are with.
892307CE-55CC-40BC-AB60-B0BB0B97DE8E
utterance can be shaped by context and utterances can shape the context.
Pragmatics is the study meaning in context the meaning of things we actually say in conversation.
45EBBDC4-4B2B-4320-BB5B-47F6EFCB0B28
indexicals: refer to speaker (I), hearer (you), the utterance location (here) and the utterance time (now).
demonstratives: point to things in the context (that, this, these, those)
third person pronouns point to people/things in the context or previous utterances.
certain words in languages depend on the external context of the conversation to have a meaning:
context shapes the meaning of utterances
assertive speech act (commit to the truth): i affirm that
expressive speech act (expresses attitude): i regret that
declarative speech act (alters external context): i now pronounce you man and wife. i declare you innocent of all charges.
certain words/phrases in languages can shape the context and perform actions. we call these speech acts.
utterances shape context
conversational participants: at least two, a speaker and a listener
conversational topic: two broad categories, person-centred and world-centred.
conversational goal: two main goals, exchange information or establish/maintain social bonds.
cooperative principle: we assume the person we are speaking with is making the best contribution possible.
1. the maxim of quality: be truthful
2. the maxim of quantity: be informative
3. the maxim of relevance: be relevant
4. the maxim of manner: be clear

these maxims should not be interpreted as advice for having a good conversation. we assume that these maxims are the default setting. following the maxims is what leads to saying one thing, but implying something else. leas to conversational implicatures.
four conventional maxims:
how to make the best contribution?
conversation is a social interaction and like all social interactions it follows certain social conventions.
conversational strategy: make the best contribution you can and make it at the best time.
we speak most of our utterances in conversation.
Utterances in context
PRAGMATICS
Semantics and Pragmatics
Semantics and Pragmatics
